headline: Woolies' boss Banducci and former QBE boss O'Halloran shake the box for Salvos
text:
There's nothing like guilt to encourage people to open their wallets and donate to a good cause.

Former QBE chief executive Frank O'Halloran gave corporate-types a prod when he launched The Salvation Army's 52nd annual Red Shield Appeal at the Westin in Sydney on Thursday.

O'Halloran, chairman of the Territorial Appeal and Fund Development committee, told the assembled crowd that corporate support for the Salvos "had not been as strong as we would have liked". Hint, hint.

Complementing O'Halloran's guilt trip effort was Woolworths chief executive Brad Banducci, the guest speaker – who went on to enumerate the grocer's efforts to improve the lives of the less fortunate, which include setting up a disaster support unit with the Salvos.
summary:
Former QBE chief executive Frank O'Halloran gave corporate-types a prod when he launched The Salvation Army's 52nd annual Red Shield Appeal at the Westin in Sydney on Thursday.
There's nothing like guilt to encourage people to open their wallets and donate to a good cause.
O'Halloran, chairman of the Territorial Appeal and Fund Development committee, told the assembled crowd that corporate support for the Salvos "had not been as strong as we would have liked".
Complementing O'Halloran's guilt trip effort was Woolworths chief executive Brad Banducci, the guest speaker – who went on to enumerate the grocer's efforts to improve the lives of the less fortunate, which include setting up a disaster support unit with the Salvos.
Hint, hint.
